transcripts.text: This is super heartwarming.  In Pennsylvania, a representative, Stephanie Borowicz, she's a Republican from central Pennsylvania's Clinton County.
Whoa, wait, you sure you want to say what party she's from?  We could have guessed.

Oh yeah, we could have played, let's guess what party she's from.  You know what they say about Pennsylvania, right?  It's like Philadelphia and Pittsburgh and Alabama in between.  Well, she decided to reach out.  And on the day when the Pennsylvania House would be welcoming their first Muslim uh... lawmaker uh... to the house uh... she came up to give a uh... a welcoming prayer.  i guess uh... opening the session with the prayer uh... welcoming uh... their their new colleague.  And here it is.  Think how welcoming this is for someone who is maybe not Christian or even someone who is Christian, but particularly for someone who is not Christian.  The idea that this is going on in a state house, well, here we go.  Representative Borowitz.

Thank you, Speaker.  Let's pray.  Jesus, I thank you for this privilege, Lord, of letting me pray, God, that I, Jesus, am your ambassador here today, standing here representing you, the King of kings, the Lord of lords, the great I am, the one who's coming back again, the one who came, died, and rose again on the third day.  And I'm so privileged to stand here today.  So thank you for this honor, Jesus.  God, for those that came before us like George Washington and Valley Forge and Abraham Lincoln who sought after you in Gettysburg.  Jesus, and the founding fathers in Independence Hall.  Jesus, that sought after you and fasted and prayed for this nation to be founded on your principles and your words and your truths.  God, forgive us.  Jesus, we've lost sight of you.

I just want to just go back a little bit.  It's easy to get caught up in the rhythm, but she's saying that... This country was founded on Jesus' principles, which I'm quite sure.  religious liberty was up there, wasn't it, a little bit?
You know, we get a bad rap, but are Jews really this melodramatic when we pray?
Jesus Christ.
They like the Greeks as much as they like Jesus.
Yeah, but who gave the Greeks what they got?
But wait a second.
Jesus.

It's one thing to say, Jesus, thank you for America, and Jesus, everything that we have in America is a function of us.  following your word, Jesus.  But Jesus, forgive us for what we're doing today, she wants to say.

Jesus, that sought after you and fasted and prayed for this nation to be founded on your principles and your words and your truths.  God, forgive us.  Jesus, we've lost sight of you.  We've forgotten you, God, in our country.  And we're asking you to forgive us, Jesus, that your promise and your word says that if my people who are called by my name will humble themselves and pray and seek your face and turn from their wicked ways, that you'll heal our land.  Jesus, you are our only hope.  God, I pray for our leader, Speaker Terzi, Leader Cutler, Governor Wolf, President Trump.  Lord, thank you that he stands beside Israel unequivocally, Lord.  Thank you that Jesus... That we're blessed because we stand by Israel and we ask for the peace of Jerusalem as your word says, God.  We ask that we not be overcome by evil and that we overcome evil with good in this land once again.  I claim all these things in the powerful, mighty name of Jesus, the one who at the name of Jesus, every knee will bow and every tongue will confess that you are Lord.  In Jesus' name, amen.  Yeah.
People were saying like, you know, I don't like the part about how every knee shall bow.  That probably is maybe going a little too far.  Someone yells out.
I mean, we start our morning.  It's can we start praying in morning prep?  Actually, that was kind of cool.
Every knee shall bow.  We can each choose our own God.
Hashem, thank you.  And thank you, Hashem, for those who made social security reports.
And Jesus, I pray that you let us come in a little bit later on Mondays.
And Jesus, I hope that Sam got some sleep.  Put Jesus...

Put... Put a marker in what you said about Israel.  Because I got a story in Haaretz about how Bibi Netanyahu told an aide, I don't need AIPAC anymore because I have the evangelicals.  But I guess he likes it because they still pay his way when he comes to the States or something.
Still a free trip, and my son gets to meet Sepp Gorka, which is a big deal for him.  Hopefully we'll keep him from being the first school shooter in Israel, huh?
Speaking of which, where is he?

So here is Representative Movida Johnson Harrell.  She is the first in the state as, I should say, the first state representative sworn in as the first Muslim woman representative.  And here is... Here's her, I mean, first of all, that they picked this woman, like, did the leader of the chamber not realize that we're going to find the, I mean, was this a surprise to anybody?  That's what's really offensive.  You can always find some person who is a religious fanatic who thinks that their religion is uber ales.  And but you don't pick that person to give the opening remarks, particularly on a day.  Frankly, I would say the time for you to pick them is never.  But certainly on this day, you're culpable, too, buddy.  But here is Movita Johnson-Harrell.
That prayer in the beginning is meant to be inclusive and to bring everyone together.  We as Republican and Democrat can find many, many things to fight about.  Prayer should not be one of them.
In the name of Jesus, every knee will bow and every tongue will confess, Jesus, that you are Lord.
I thought that was political, but I also thought it was a political statement when she talked about everyone will bow a knee and talking about how people are not Christian, that they are condemned.
Your promise and your word says that if my people who are called by my name will humble themselves and pray and seek your face and turn from their wicked ways.

It was directly a political statement.  And I think we need to be very, very clear that everybody in this house matters, whether they're Christian, Muslim or Jew, and that we cannot use those issues to tear each other down.  And not only that, it was it was made during my swearing in.  I, Movita Johnson-Harrell, which was a moment not only for my district and my city, but for the entire Commonwealth.  To be the first hijabi woman to stand on the statehouse floor to be elected to the House is great for the entire Commonwealth.  So to use my religion against me and to then storm off the floor, I thought, number one, was very, very immature, and, number two, very, very disrespectful.
To say the least.
Yeah.
I mean, I thought the opportunity of my swearing in for a theocratic fascist threat was a little bit unseemly.
I mean, honestly, just unbelievable.

Oh, yeah, I saw that.  But what about the tax thing?  I read a translation that Muhammad wasn't a nice guy.  Majority report doing apologetics for Muslims.  Yeah, I hear what you're saying about.  maybe she shouldn't have done that prayer.  And I don't like Christianity either, but... I feel like you got a question.  Why would the assembly woman be a Muslim?  There's a thing called the Hadith, which I've heard about on several podcasts.

To be fair, look, we're not going to get to many calls today at all, folks.  So don't hang on to too long.  But one of those calls could be someone who was a Christian who is calling in and wants to talk about what that means, that we've got to take the knee, because we know historically what that means when you did not take the knee.  We have examples of that during the Spanish Inquisition, in fact, when you did not take the knee.  And certainly... You know, I don't want to say that Christianity is the mother of all bad ideas, but certainly when you see... I mean, it's just...

It kind of makes me realize why they have a thing like laïcité in France, where it's just like all religion.  There's a blanket ban on it in public municipal life.  Like, I don't think we need to go that far.  People just need to not be psychos about it.  But this woman is making me think maybe we do.
I mean, it's pretty disturbing.

If we did, who would it be targeted at?  Not that woman.  Just as in France.  Why these are bad policy ideas?  I mean, I get your sentiment.  I actually have more sympathy for it than people might think.  But it's about power and what it gets instrumentalized against.  And actually... Right there is a perfect example of that.  There is a Muslim woman who's quite happy to have a civil polity where people could express their faith.  And there's literally a theocratic fascist trying to terrorize her out of her job.
We could at least put like a time limit on how long you're allowed to go on for when you're doing that kind of talk.
Yeah.  And, you know, I really do think that probably you could have given that little diatribe maybe in your own home.  Jesus probably would have heard you if he's so powerful.
I got the sense that she was practicing that in her own home.
I bet.  I bet.
